Description: Deficient Filer
Info Source: Included in a dataset downloaded at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Company is plan administrator. Penalty amount reported in range of $50,001 to $100,000.

Description: The SEC announced an enforcement action against current and former brokerage subsidiaries of E*TRADE Financial Corporation that failed in their gatekeeper roles and improperly engaged in unregistered sales of microcap stocks on behalf of their customers. E*TRADE Securities and G1 Execution Services agreed to settle the SEC?' charges by paying back more than $1.5 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest from commissions they earned on the improper sales as well as a combined penalty of $1 million.

Agency: District of Columbia Department of Insurance, Securities and Banking

Description: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $500,000 to settle allegations that it misled clients about the money managers being recommended to them and failing to disclose conflicts of interest.
The Justice Department announced that Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a $2.6 billion penalty to resolve claims related to its marketing, sale and issuance of residential mortgage-backed securities.

The Federal Housing Finance Agency announced a settlement with Morgan Stanley resolving alleged violations of federal and state securities laws and common law fraud in connection with private-label mortgage-backed securities purchased by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac between 2005 and 2007.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that three Morgan Stanley settled allegagtions that they misled investors in a pair of residential mortgage-backed securities securitizations that the firms underwrote, sponsored, and issued.

Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley reached agreements in principle with the Federal Reserve Board to pay $557 million in cash payments and other assistance to help mortgage borrowers. The Fed did not announce how the amount would be divided between the two companies but the Wall Street Journal reported on January 17, 2013 that Morgan Stanley's share would be $227 million.

The National Credit Union Administration announced a settlement with Morgan Stanley for $225 million to resolve claims arising from losses related to corporate credit unions' purchases of faulty residential mortgage-backed securities.

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Morgan Stanley announced a $54 million settlement of a sex discrimination lawsuit under Title VII of the 1964 Civil Rights Act filed on behalf of a class of female officers and women eligible for officer promotion in the firm's Institutional Equity Division.
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges that, over an 18-month period, Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC unlawfully executed, processed, and reported numerous off-exchange futures trades.

The Department of Justice announced a settlement with Morgan Stanley that required Morgan to pay $4.8 million for violating the antitrust laws by entering into an agreement with KeySpan Corporation that restrained competition in the New York City electricity capacity market. The department said the agreement likely resulted in a price increase for electricity retailers, which, in turn, led to increased electricity prices for consumers.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order requiring Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC to pay a $300,000 civil monetary penalty for failing to hold sufficient U.S. Dollars in segregated accounts in the United States to meet all of its U.S. Dollar obligations to cleared swaps customers.

Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs each agreed to pay $40 million to settle allegations relating to the firms' allocations of stock to institutional customers in initial public offerings (IPOs) underwritten by the firms during 1999 and 2000.

Morgan Stanley & Co. agreed to pay $10 million to settle allegations that it failed to maintain and enforce adequate written policies and procedures to prevent the misuse of material nonpublic information, commonly referred to as inside information.

Morgan Stanley & Co. agreed to pay $10 million to settle allegations that it failed to produce tens of thousands of e-mails during the SEC's IPO and Research Analyst investigations from Dec. 11, 2000, through at least July 2005.

The SEC -- along with the New York Attorney General, the North American Securities Administrators Association, NASD, the New York Stock Exchange and state securities regulators -- announced the completion of enforcement actions against ten of the nation's top investment firms joint investigations of allegations of undue influence of investment banking interests on securities research at brokerage firms.
Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated agreed to pay more than $7.9 million to settle allegations that it failed to provide best execution to certain retail orders for over-the-counter (OTC) securities.

The SEC brought and settled civil administrative fraud charges against ten Wall Street and regional brokerage firms for overcharging municipalities for government securities in a practice commonly known as yield burning.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, as receiver for three failed banks, announced a $62.95 million settlement of residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) claims against Morgan Stanley & Company LLC.

The Securities and Exchange Commission penalized Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC for violating the market access rule when it failed to uphold credit limits for a customer firm with a rogue trader who engaged in fraudulent trading of Apple stock.
The SEC announced enforcement actions against 36 municipal underwriting firms for violations in municipal bond offerings.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced the separate filings and simultaneous settlements of charges against Morgan Stanley Capital Group, Inc. and UBS Securities Inc. in connection with Morgan Stanley's alleged concealment from the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX) the existence of a large Trade at Settlement (TAS) block crude oil trade. UBS Securities allegedly aided and abetted that concealment.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission announced that Morgan Stanley Capital Group Inc. agreed to pay a $200,000 civil monetary penalty to settle CFTC charges that it exceeded speculative position limits in soybean meal futures contracts trading on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Morgan Stanley DW Inc. agreed to pay $50 million to settle allegations that it failed to provide customers important information relating to their purchases of mutual fund shares.
Morgan Stanley Smith Barney agreed to pay an $8 million penalty and admit wrongdoing to settle allegations related to single inverse ETF investments it recommended to advisory clients.

Morgan Stanley Smith Barney and Citigroup Global Markets agreed to pay more than $2.96 million apiece to settle allegations that they made false and misleading statements about a foreign exchange trading program they sold to investors.
The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, LLC for improper supervision and records violations.
Morgan Stanley Smith Barney agreed to pay a $13 million penalty to settle charges that it overbilled investment advisory clients due to coding and other billing system errors.

The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC for violating CFTC rules governing secured funds of foreign futures and option customers, commingling customer and firm funds, failing to prepare accurate daily computations of its segregated and secured funds, failing to properly title account statements for four customer segregated accounts, and failing to diligently supervise its employees handling of matters related to its business as a CFTC registrant.
The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order settling charges that Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC failed to diligently supervise its employees' handling of customer accounts.
Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC agreed to pay a $1 million penalty to settle charges related to its failures to protect customer information, some of which was hacked and offered for sale online.

Saxon Mortgage Services Inc., a subsidiary of Morgan Stanley, agreed to pay $2.35 million to resolve a lawsuit alleging that Saxon foreclosed on approximately 17 servicemembers between January 2006 and June 2009 without court orders.

Company: Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated/ Morgan Stanley DW Inc.
Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement of proceedings against 15 broker-dealer firms for engaging in violative practices in the auction rate securities market.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Morgan Stanley Investment Management settled allegations of  violating securities laws in a fee arrangement that repeatedly charged a fund and its investors for advisory services they weren't actually receiving from a third party.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that Morgan Stanley Investment Management agreed to pay $8.8 million to settle charges that one of its portfolio managers unlawfully conducted prearranged trading known as "parking" that favored certain advisory client accounts over others.
race and national origin
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: The SEC brought and settled civil administrative fraud charges against ten Wall Street and regional brokerage firms for overcharging municipalities for government securities in a practice commonly known as yield burning.

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and simultaneously settling charges against Morgan Stanley, a registered Futures Commission Merchant (FCM), for non-compliance with applicable rules governing Part 17 Large Trader reports to the CFTC spanning a ten-year period and affecting thousands of line items of information.

The Commodity Futures Trading Commission issued an Order filing and simultaneously settling charges against Morgan Stanley for failing to diligently supervise the reconciliation of exchange and clearing fees with the amounts it ultimately charged customers for certain transactions on the CME Group, ICE Futures US, and other exchanges.
overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Devries v. Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC et al; Jason Zajonc v. Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC et al; Johnson v. Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, et al; Hix v. Morgan Stanley & Co., LLC et al

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Amador v. Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Palacio v. E* Trade Financial Corporation et al

Description: misclassification
Private Litigation Case Title: Steinberg et al v. Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated et al

Description: misclassification
Private Litigation Case Title: Clarence L Simpson v. E Trade Securities Incorporated et al

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Garett, et al v. Morgan Stanley and C, et al

Description: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney agreed to pay a $3.6 million penalty and to accept certain undertakings for its failure to protect against its personnel misusing or misappropriating funds from client accounts.
Racial discrimination.
Private Litigation Case Title: Jaffe, et al v. Morgan Stanley Dw, Inc.
Dodson v. Morgan Stanley DW Inc

Court: District of the District of Columbia
Private Litigation Case Title: Augst-Johnson et al v. Morgan Stanley DW, Inc.
Amochaev et al v. Citigroup Global Markets Inc. dba Smith Barney

Description: Online retail brokers E*Trade and TradeKing agreed to pay a total of $200,000 as part of the settlement of a lawsuit brought by Connecticut, Iowa and Missouri alleging potential violations of antitrust law. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided equally between them.

JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley agreed to buy back $7 billion in securities as part of the resolution of multistate litigation alleging they misled customers in the marketing and sale of auction rate securities. The announcement did not specify how much each company would buy back. Here we assume the total was divided evenly between them. They also agreed to pay civil penalties; for Morgan Stanley the amount was $35 million.

Ten major brokerage houses agreed to take steps to address conflicts of interest in their securities research work and pay $1.3 billion in penalties to settle multistate litigation. The penalties were also announced later by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission after it had approved the settlements; see the Violation Tracker entry for Morgan Stanley at: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-stanley-and-co-incorporated-0
Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $150 million to resolve allegations that it misled state pension funds and other investors about the risks of mortgage-backed securities.
Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $22.5 million in settlement of allegations of misconduct in the marketing and sale of risky mortgage-backed securities leading up to the 2008 economic collapse.
failure to disclose the risks of auction-rate securities

The New York Attorney General announced a $550 million settlement with Morgan Stanley to resolve allegations of deceptive practices in the marketing, sale and issuance of residential mortgage-backed securities in the period leading up to the financial crisis. This was announced at the same time that the federal government announced a $2.6 billion settlement with Morgan Stanley on the same issue; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-stanley-1

Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $102 million to affected parties in Massachusetts in settlement of allegations it provided financing for subprime loans and secured those loans while ignoring legal requirements and its own guidelines to correctly assess the risk of those loans to the borrower and investor.

Morgan Stanley agreed to return the funds invested by various Massachusetts municipalities in Auction Rate Securities. This was in settlement of allegations it misled the investors that the securities were permissable investments under Massachusetts law.
misrepresentation of mortgage-backed securities
alleged fuel price-gouging by TransMontaigne subsidiary
Info Source: McCollum, Bronson Announce Groundbreaking Settlement in Morgan Stanley Price Gouging Investigation, Targeted News Service, July 13, 2009 (via Nexis).

Description: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $700,000 in settlement of a state administrative action alleging that improperly supervised brokers who executed numerous unauthorized and unsuitable securities transactions in the brokerage accounts of a married couple.

Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $7.2 million to the state and provide $20 million-$40 million in mortgage relief to homeowners to resolve an investigation into the firm's role in purchasing and securitizing roughly 3,000 subprime mortgages in Nevada.

Ten major brokerage houses agreed to take steps to address conflicts of interest in their securities research work and pay $1.3 billion in penalties to settle multistate litigation. The penalties were also announced later by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission after it had approved the settlements; see the Violation Tracker entry for Salomon Smith Barney at: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-citigroup-global-markets-inc-fka-salomon
spoofing violation

The New York Attorney General Spitzer announced a settlement with Morgan Stanley DW Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Morgan Stanley, for failing to supervise one of its brokers who defrauded 15 customers of more than $740,000.

Agency: Alaska Division of Banking and Securities
California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation

Description: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $5 million in settlement of an Administrative Order alleging multiple violations of securities regulations, including failing to to maintain its records correctly and failing to supervise the activities of its agents and office operations to ensure they were correctly trained in and following securities regulations.
Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division
Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Description: Morgan Stanley DW agreed to pay $415,000 in restitution, costs, and contributions to consumer education in settlement of allegations one of its Financial Advisors recommended unsuitable investments and engaged in unauthorized trading, inappropriate use of margin, and excessive trading.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter agreed to pay $100,000 to the state Investor Protection Trust in settlement of allegations it allowed the beneficiary of a trust account to be designated as investment adviser for the trust, and failed to supervise an agent trading in the trust account, resulting in unsuitable investments. Procedural changes and restitution had already occurred before the settlement.
Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a $5 million administrative penalty in settlement of allegations that its investment banking operation had improper influence over research analysts.

Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a $1 million administrative penalty in settlement of allegations it failed to supervise financial advisors, leading to an incentive scheme that could encourage inappropriate financial advice.

Info Source: DLLR OBTAINS REFUNDS FOR CONSUMERS OVER IMPROPER CHARGES, States News Servikce, July 1, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay a $100,000 penalty, $400,000 in costs, and set up a $4,243,815 Customer Fund for restitution in settlement of allegations it failed to supervise  its agents leading to unsuitable investments for clients.

Company: Eaton Vance Income Fund of Boston

Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
Info Source: N.H. seeks to fine Morgan Stanley $500,000 for improper sales contests, Associated Press, June 24, 2004 (via Nexis).

Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Description: recommendation of unsuitable investments by one of its financial advisors
Agency: Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation

Description: improper marketing of banking services by financial advisors
Agency: Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation
Washington State Department of Financial Institutions
Washington State Department of Financial Institutions

Description: E*TRADE agreed to pay $5 million to a group of states to resolve allegations the company failed to warn investors about the risks of auction-rate preferred securities.

Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $35 million to a group of states to resolve litigation alleging it failed to properly inform investors about the risks of auction-rate securities. The settlement was also announced by the New York Attorney General; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-stanley-19
Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $8.5 million to a group of states to resolve allegations that it engaged in the sale of unregistered securities.

Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $25 million to a group of states to settle allegations that its investment banking interests had undue influence on its securities research. This was part of a larger $125 million settlement involving the SEC; see the Violation Tracker https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-stanley-and-co-incorporated-0

Notes: Penalty includes $1,000 in back licensing fees.

Agency: Pennsylvania Department of Banking and Securities
South Dakota Division of Insurance-Securities Regulation

Company: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney FA Notes Holdings LLC
Description: Unlawful California Financing Law Activity
Agency: California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation

Description: swap data violations
vendor management control deficiences
Agency: Office of the Comptroller of the Currency
Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Description: FINRA sanctioned five firms-Citigroup Global Markets Inc.; J.P. Morgan Securities LLC; LPL Financial LLC; Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC; and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Incorporated-for failing to reasonably supervise compliance with FINRA Rule 2090, FINRA's Know Your Customer rule. In settling this matter, the five firms paid combined fines totaling $1.4 million, and agreed to review their policies, systems, and procedures to ensure that they are reasonably designed to supervise custodial accounts and to achieve compliance with FINRA Rule 2090.  The firms neither admitted nor denied the charges, but consented to the entry of FINRA's findings. FINRA's announcement did not specify how much each firm was fined. Here we assume the $1.4 million was divided equally among them.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: FINRA fined Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC $10 million for anti-money laundering program and supervisory failures that spanned a period of more than five years.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined TradeStation Securities, Inc., E-Trade Securities, LLC and CIBC World Markets Corp. for multi-year violations relating to FINRA's Order Audit Trail System (OATS) rules and related supervisory failures.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC $3.25 million and required the firm to pay approximately $9.78 million in restitution to more than 3,000 affected customers for failing to supervise its representatives' short-term trades of unit investment trusts (UITs).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority censured and fined E-Trade Securities LLC $900,000 for failing to conduct an adequate review of the quality of execution of its customers' orders and for supervisory deficiencies concerning the protection of customer order information.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, LLC $650,000 and Scottrade, Inc. $300,000 for failing to implement reasonable supervisory systems to monitor the transmittal of customer funds to third-party accounts. Both firms were cited for the weak supervisory systems by FINRA examination teams in 2011, but neither took necessary steps to correct the supervisory gaps.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC $2 million for short interest reporting and short sale rule violations that spanned a period of more than six years, and for failing to implement a supervisory system reasonably designed to detect and prevent such violations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined 10 firms a total of $43.5 million for allowing their equity research analysts to solicit investment banking business and for offering favorable research coverage in connection with the 2010 planned initial public offering of Toys R Us.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC $5,000,000 for supervisory failures related to the solicitation of retail customers to invest in initial public offerings (IPOs). From February 16, 2012, to May 1, 2013, Morgan Stanley Smith Barney sold shares to retail customers in 83 IPOs, including Facebook and Yelp, without having adequate procedures and training to ensure that its sales staff distinguished between indications of interest and conditional offers in its solicitations of potential investors.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC and Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC and Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC $1 million and ordered $188,000 in restitution plus interest for failing to provide best execution in certain customer transactions involving corporate and agency bonds, and failing to provide a fair and reasonable price in certain customer transactions involving municipal bonds.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority sanctioned five firms for unfairly obtaining the reimbursement of fees they paid to the California Public Securities Association (Cal PSA) from the proceeds of municipal and state bond offerings.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority sanctioned Citigroup Global Markets, Inc; Morgan Stanley & Co., LLC; UBS Financial Services; and Wells Fargo Advisors, LLC for selling leveraged and inverse exchange-traded funds (ETFs) without reasonable supervision and for not having a reasonable basis for recommending the securities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc. and Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc. and Morgan Stanley Smith Barney LLC $1 million and ordered $371,000 in restitution and interest to customers for excessive markups and markdowns charged to customers on corporate and municipal bond transactions, and related supervision violations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority censured and fined Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc. $800,000 for failing to make public disclosures required by FINRA's rules governing research analyst conflicts of interest. The firm also failed to comply with a key provision of the 2003 Research Analyst Settlement by failing to disclose the availability of independent research in customer account statements.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley & Co. $3 million - and ordered it to pay more than $4.2 million in restitution to 90 Rochester, NY-area retirees - to resolve charges that its supervisory system failed to detect and prevent brokers from persuading Eastman Kodak Company and Xerox Corporation employees to take early retirement based upon unrealistic promises of consistently high investment returns and by espousing unsuitable investment strategies.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Company: E-Trade Securities LLC and E-Trade Clearing LLC
Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined E-Trade $1 million for failing to implement reasonable anti-money laundering (AML) compliance programs.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority announced a settlement with Morgan Stanley & Co. to resolve charges that the firm's former affiliate, Morgan Stanley DW, Inc., failed on numerous occasions to provide emails to claimants in arbitration proceedings as well as to regulators - while representing that the destruction of the firm's email servers in the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on New York's World Trade Center resulted in the loss of all pre-9/11 email. In fact, the firm had millions of pre-9/11 emails that had been restored to the firm's active email system using back-up tapes that had been stored in another location. The settlement provided for distribution of $9.5 million to two groups of customers who had arbitration claims against the firm. FINRA also imposed a $3 million fine on the firm for its failure to provide pre-9/11 emails and updates to a supervisory manual.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Morgan Stanley DW Inc. $1.5 million and ordered the firm to pay more than $4.6 million in restitution for rule violations relating to the sale of corporate bonds to retail customers at excessive prices. The firm was cited for charging excessive mark-ups in more than 2,800 transactions and for having an inadequate supervisory system for monitoring the pricing of corporate fixed income securities sold to customers.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling $850,000 against four firms for failing to have adequate supervisory systems and procedures to identify opportunities for investors to purchase Class A mutual fund shares at net asset value (NAV), or without a front-end sales charge.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling $2.9 million against Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc. and Morgan Stanley DW Inc. for extensive violations dealing with reporting obligations, best execution, short sales and a range of other NASD, Securities and Exchange Commission and Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board rules.
Info Source: NASD Fines Morgan Stanley Firms $2.9 Million for Widespread Violations of NASD Rules, PR Newswire, September 5, 2006 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling $775,000 against Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., Credit Suisse Securities (USA), LLC and Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated for numerous violations of NASD's research analyst conflict of interest rules.
Info Source: NASD fines Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Associated Press, July 17, 2006 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined Morgan Stanley DW, Inc. $1.5 million and ordered the firm to pay more than $4.6 million in restitution for failing to adequately supervise its fee-based brokerage business.
Info Source: NASD Orders Morgan Stanley to Pay over $6.1 Million for Fee-Based Account Violations, PR Newswire, August 2, 2005 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered three firms-Morgan Stanley & Co, J.P. Morgan Securities, Inc., and Goldman, Sachs & Co.-to pay more than $2.9 million following sales of restricted securities in violation of lock-up agreements as required by NASD rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD sanctioned Morgan Stanley DW Inc. for failing to disclose to purchasers of municipal bonds that those bonds could be called prior their stated maturity dates, which could result in losses to the investors.
Info Source: NASD Fines Morgan Stanley $100,000 for Municipal Bond Disclosure Violations, PR Newswire, December 6, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined Morgan Stanley DW Inc. $2.2 million for more than 1,800 late disclosures of reportable information about its brokers. The late reports concerned, among other things, customer complaints and disciplinary actions by regulators. NASD also charged Morgan Stanley for supervisory failures relating to the late filings.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD announced today that it has censured and fined Citigroup Global Markets, Inc. (formerly Salomon Smith Barney); Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Incorporated; and Morgan Stanley DW Inc. $250,000 each for failing to comply with their discovery obligations in 20 arbitration cases during the period 2002 through 2004.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered eight firms to pay fines totaling $310,000 and restitution to customers of $300,000 in connection with certain municipal bond trades where customers did not receive a fair price for their bonds, in violation of Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSRB) rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured three major investment banks and imposed monetary sanctions of more than $15 million for engaging in improper Initial Public Offering (IPO) allocation practices.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD sanctioned Morgan Stanley DW Inc. for giving preferential treatment to certain mutual fund companies in return for millions of dollars in brokerage commissions. In conjunction with a related action filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), Morgan Stanley agreed to resolve the NASD and SEC actions by paying $50 million in civil penalties and surrendered profits. The penalty was also announced by the SEC; see the separate entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-stanley-dw-inc
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined Morgan Stanley DW Inc. $2 million for conducting prohibited sales contests for its brokers and managers to promote the sale of Morgan Stanley mutual funds and a selected few variable annuities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD announced actions against five broker-dealers for violations of record-keeping requirements concerning e-mail communications. The firms consented to the imposition of fines totaling $8.25 million, along with a requirement to review their procedures to ensure compliance with record-keeping statutes and rules. The case was brought jointly with the SEC, which also announced the penalty: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-morgan-stanley-and-co-incorporated-1
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD announced actions against five broker-dealers for violations of record-keeping requirements concerning e-mail communications. The firms consented to the imposition of fines totaling $8.25 million, along with a requirement to review their procedures to ensure compliance with record-keeping statutes and rules. The case was brought jointly with the SEC, which also announced the penalty: https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-salomon-smith-barney-inc
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined Salomon Smith Barney $5 million for issuing materially misleading research reports in 2001 on Winstar Communications, Inc.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD Regulation, Inc., announced that E*Trade Securities was censured and fined $90,000 for NASD advertising rule and supervisory system violations. In settling this matter, E*Trade neither admitted nor denied NASD Regulation's allegations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: The American Stock Exchange, LLC, NASD Regulation, Inc., and the New York Stock Exchange, Inc., as a result of a coordinated investigation, announced that Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc. consented to a censure and $200,000 fine for violations arising from the inaccurate reporting of short interest from November 1996 to August 1998.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD Regulation, Inc. censured and fined E*TRADE Securities, Inc. $20,000 for failing to report its short interest positions for a twenty-eight month period. Additionally, NASD Regulation, Inc. found that the firm failed to establish, maintain and enforce written supervisory procedures reasonably designed to ensure compliance with the short interest reporting rule.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD Regulation, Inc., censured and fined E*TRADE Securities, Inc., of Menlo Park, CA, $20,000 for failing to promptly respond to NASD Regulation requests for information relating to customer complaints.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD Regulation's National Adjudicatory Council censured and fined New York-based Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., $495,000 for manipulating the prices of nine securities that underlie the Nasdaq 100 Index (NDX) on two separate expiration Fridays in 1995 and for causing locked and crossed markets to occur in nine stocks.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
